result.execSummary:
The defendant Christopher J. Valenta was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Christopher J. Valenta is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Christopher J. Valenta was found guilty of Disorderly Conduct, a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Christopher J. Valenta

Attorney Tracey Braun appeared for the State. Atty. C. Rose with DE in person. Clerk RMM
After plea of guilty, Coiurt finds DE guilty of Count 1 and dismissed Count 2 upon motion of State. Fine imposed of $50 plus costs.

Attorney Jennifer Phan appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in court in person and w/ Attorney C Rose.  Clerk/H. Barnett.  Atty Rose states the deft is in counselling and has 10 sessions left.  FPT continued to 7/15/16 at 8:45am.  Bond continued.

Attorney Carli McNeill appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in court in person and w/ Attorney C Rose.  Clerk/H. Barnett.  Victims present.  Atty Rose states the deft is in anger management treatment at Oakwood.  FPT continued to 4/22/16 at 9am.  Bond continued.

212pm  Special Prosecutor Attorney Daniel Tombasco  appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in court in person.  Clerk JThwing. Minutes:  Def. is referred to the Public Defender.  If not eligible, def. to retain his own counsel. Court date will not be adjourned due to def.'s failure to retain counsel.  Plea of Not Guilty entered.  Deft demands jury trial.
